label: BODY

text: This is a decision on appeal under 35 U.S.C. § 134(a) from the
label: H4

text: Examiner’s Final Rejection of claims 1—20. We have jurisdiction under 35
label: H4

text: We Affirm.
label: BODY

text: The Invention
label: BODY

text: The claimed invention relates to “a display control device comprising
label: BODY

text: a determining unit configured to determine an orientation of a real object in
label: BODY

text: a real space image.” Abstract.
label: H4

text: Application 13/435,967
label: BODY

text: Representative Claim
label: BODY

text: A display control device comprising:
label: BODY

text: a determining unit configured to determine an orientation
label: BODY

text: angle of a real object in a real space image in relation to an
label: BODY

text: optical axis of the real space image;
label: BODY

text: a control unit configured to:
label: BODY

text: select between a first virtual object orientation and a
label: BODY

text: second virtual object orientation of a virtual object based on
label: BODY

text: the real object orientation angle, wherein the first virtual object
label: BODY

text: orientation is on substantially the same plane as a surface of the
label: BODY

text: real object in the real space image and the second virtual object
label: BODY

text: orientation is in a different plane than the surface of the real
label: BODY

text: object in the real space image; and
label: BODY

text: output an image on a display device of the virtual object
label: BODY

text: with the selected orientation at least partially superimposed on
label: BODY

text: the real object.
label: BODY

text: (Contested “select” clause limitation emphasized)
label: BODY

text: Rejections
label: BODY

text: A. Claims 1—10 and 12—20 are rejected under 35 U.S.C. § 103(a) as
label: H4

text: being obvious over the combined teachings and suggestions of Zimmerman
label: BODY

text: et al. (“Zimmerman”) (US 2012/0113141 Al, published May 10, 2012) and
label: BODY

text: Jetha et al. (“Jetha”) (US 6,661,426 Bl, issued Dec. 9, 2003).
label: BODY

text: B. Claim 11 is rejected under 35 U.S.C. § 103(a) as being obvious
label: BODY

text: over the combined teachings and suggestions of Zimmerman, Jetha, and
label: BODY

text: Whytock et al. (“Whytock”) (US 2010/0177931 Al, published July 15,
label: BODY

text: Application 13/435,967
label: BODY

text: Claim Grouping
label: BODY

text: Based on Appellant’s arguments (Supp. App. Br. 11—19), we decide
label: H4

text: the appeal of rejection A of claims 1—10 and 12—20 based on representative
label: BODY

text: independent claim 1. We address rejection B of remaining dependent
label: H4

text: claim 11, argued separately, infra. See 37 C.F.R. § 41.37(c)(l)(iv).
label: H4

text: ANALYSIS
label: BODY

text: We have considered all of Appellant’s arguments and any evidence
label: BODY

text: presented. We disagree with Appellant’s contentions regarding the
label: H4

text: Examiner’s obviousness rejections of the claims. We adopt as our own:
label: H4

text: (1) the findings and legal conclusions set forth by the Examiner in the action
label: BODY

text: from which this appeal is taken, and (2) the findings, legal conclusions, and
label: BODY

text: explanations set forth in the Answer in response to Appellant’s arguments.
label: BODY

text: We highlight and address specific findings and arguments for emphasis in
label: BODY

text: our analysis below.
label: BODY

text: Rejection A of Independent Claim 1 under 35 U.S.C. § 103(a)
label: BODY

text: Issue: Under § 103, did the Examiner err by finding the cited
label: H4

text: combination of references would have taught or suggested the contested
label: BODY

text: “select” clause limitation, within the meaning of representative claim 1,
label: BODY

text: under a broad but reasonable interpretation? 1
label: BODY

text: 1 We give the contested claim limitations the broadest reasonable
label: BODY

text: interpretation consistent with the Specification. See In re Morris, 111 F.3d
label: H4

text: 1048, 1054 (Fed. Circ. 1997). See e.g., Spec. 1110 (“Although preferred
label: H4

text: embodiments of the present disclosure are described above with reference to
label: BODY

text: the appended drawings, the present disclosure is not limited thereto. It
label: BODY

text: should be understood by those skilled in the art that various modifications,
label: BODY

text: combinations, subcombinations and alterations may occur depending on
label: BODY

text: Application 13/435,967
label: BODY

text: Regarding the contested “select” clause limitation of independent
label: BODY

text: claim 1, Appellant contends:
label: BODY

text: Jetha does not have any disclosure, teaching, or suggestion
label: H4

text: relating to selecting orientations of a virtual object based on the
label: BODY

text: orientation of a real object. In fact, Jetha does not relate to the
label: BODY

text: combination of real objects and virtual objects in a display
label: H4

text: scenario.
label: BODY

text: (Supp. App. Br. 12).
label: H4

text: Appellant further contends:
label: BODY

text: The Appellant respectfully and strenuously traverses the
label: H1

text: unsubstantiated and erroneous assertion that “the combination of
label: BODY

text: Zimmerman and Jetha teaches selecting ‘between a first virtual
label: BODY

text: object orientation and a second virtual object orientation of a
label: H4

text: virtual object based on the real object orientation angle’.” This
label: H2

text: erroneous assertion is inconsistent with the admissions on page
label: BODY

text: 7 of the Final Office Action and not supported by the actual prior
label: BODY

text: art disclosure.
label: BODY

text: (Supp. App. Br. 17).
label: H4

text: We agree with the Examiner’s conclusion that the Appellant is
label: BODY

text: arguing the references separately.*
label: BODY

text: The Examiner finds Jetha teaches selecting between first and second
label: BODY

text: orientations of ancillary data, based on the orientation of the prismatic body
label: BODY

text: (Ans. 13, citing Jetha, col. 5 lines 30—60). The Examiner finds Zimmerman
label: H4

text: design requirements and other factors insofar as they are within the scope of
label: BODY

text: the appended claims or the equivalents thereof.”) (Emphasis added).
label: BODY

text: 2 One cannot show nonobviousness by attacking references
label: BODY

text: where the rejections are based on combinations of references. In re Merck
label: H4

text: Application 13/435,967
label: BODY

text: teaches a camera capturing real objects and generating an image comprising
label: BODY

text: one or more virtual objects combined with a real object, and further teaches
label: BODY

text: changing the angle of a virtual object based on the virtual or real object
label: BODY

text: orientation on which the virtual object is superimposed. (Ans. 13—14, citing
label: H3

text: Zimmerman Fig. 1, || 14, 22, 24, 68).
label: H4

text: We find a preponderance of the evidence supports the Examiner’s
label: BODY

text: findings. Zimmerman’s augmented image (118-2), as shown in Fig. 5C, of a
label: H4

text: hand (real object 106-2, Fig. 1), is depicted holding a cell phone in multiple
label: H4

text: different positions (virtual images), where the angle of orientation of the cell
label: BODY

text: phone images depends on both the image of the hand and the virtual image
label: BODY

text: of various positions of the cell phone. We find these multiple different
label: H4

text: angled positions of the cell phone in the image of a hand teach or suggest the
label: BODY

text: contested limitation: “select between a first virtual object orientation and a
label: BODY

text: second virtual object orientation of a virtual object based on the real object
label: BODY

text: orientation angle,” as recited in claim 1. (Zimmerman | 68, Fig. 5C). As
label: H3

text: found by the Examiner, Zimmerman’s Augmented Reality System 100 (Fig.
label: BODY

text: 1), and Figure 5C, which depicts the orientation angles of the various
label: BODY

text: positions of the cell phone based on the user’s hand orientation, teach or at
label: BODY

text: least suggest the disputed limitation. (Ans. 13—14, Zimmerman | 68, Figs.
label: H3

text: Moreover, given that Zimmerman (id.) evidences that determining
label: BODY

text: orientation angles of images of objects relative to each other was well
label: BODY

text: known in the art, we find selecting between a first and second virtual object
label: BODY

text: orientation of a virtual object based on the orientation angle of a real object
label: BODY

text: would have merely produced a predictable result. On this record, Appellant
label: H4

text: has not shown that such virtual object orientation selection would have been
label: BODY

text: Application 13/435,967
label: BODY

text: more than a combination of prior art elements according to known methods
label: BODY

text: to yield predictable results. See KSR Int'l Co. v. Teleflex Inc., 550 U.S. 398,
label: H4

text: Nor has Appellant provided evidence that combining such known
label: BODY

text: elements or steps would have been “uniquely challenging or difficult for one
label: BODY

text: of ordinary skill in the art,” Leapfrog Enters., Inc. v. Fisher-Price, Inc., 485
label: BODY

text: F.3d 1157, 1162 (Fed. Cir. 2007), or would have yielded unexpected results.
label: BODY

text: Appellant argues a limitation in the Reply Brief that was not raised in
label: BODY

text: the Appeal Brief, i.e., “determine an orientation angle of a real object
label: BODY

text: (Reply Br. 4). We note arguments raised in a Reply Brief that were not
label: H4

text: raised in the Appeal Brief or are not responsive to arguments raised in the
label: BODY

text: Examiner’s Answer will not be considered except for good cause, which
label: BODY

text: Appellant has not shown. See 37 C.F.R. § 41.41(b)(2).
label: H4

text: Appellant further contends, “[I]t is apparent from the teachings of
label: BODY

text: Zimmerman that the first virtual object and the second virtual object are not
label: BODY

text: real objects.” (Reply Br. 4). We are not persuaded by Appellant’s
label: H4

text: argument, because Zimmerman’s Figure 1 and paragraph 68 both describe
label: BODY

text: real and virtual objects. Further, we agree with the Examiner’s reading of a
label: H4

text: “real object” as recited in claim 1, on Zimmerman’s hand as a real object
label: BODY

text: (Figures 1 and 5C) (Ans. 13—15; Final Act. 5—7, citing Zimmerman Fig. 1
label: H4

text: Appellant raises an untimely hindsight argument in the Reply Brief.
label: BODY

text: (Reply Br. 6), where Appellant merely alleges the Examiner has relied on
label: BODY

text: “impermissible hindsight” without presenting any substantive argument or
label: BODY

text: reasoning. Mere conclusory statements that are unsupported by factual
label: H4

text: Application 13/435,967
label: BODY

text: evidence are entitled to little probative value. In re Geisler, 116 F.3d 1465,
label: H4

text: 1470 (Fed. Cir. 1997); In re De Blauwe, 736 F.2d 699, 705 (Fed. Cir. 1984).
label: H4

text: Because Appellant has not persuaded us that the Examiner erred, we
label: BODY

text: sustain § 103 rejection A of representative independent claim 1, and the
label: BODY

text: associated grouped claims, which fall therewith. (See Grouping of Claims,
label: H3

text: supra.)
label: BODY

text: Rejection B of dependent Claim 11 under 35 U.S.C. § 103(a)
label: BODY

text: Appellant advances no separate, substantive arguments regarding
label: BODY

text: dependent claim 11, but urges this rejected claim is not obvious for the same
label: BODY

text: reasons previously advanced regarding claim 1, and that “Whytock fails to
label: BODY

text: remedy the deficiencies of Zimmerman and Jetha . . . .” (Supp. App.
label: H4

text: Br. 19). Because we find no deficiencies regarding rejection A of
label: H1

text: independent claim 1, on this record, we are not persuaded the Examiner
label: BODY

text: erred regarding rejection B of dependent claim 11. Arguments not made are
label: H4

text: waived. See 37 C.F.R. § 41.37(c)(l)(iv). Therefore, we sustain rejection B
label: H4

text: of claim 11.
label: BODY

text: Conclusion
label: BODY

text: For at least the aforementioned reasons, on this record, we are not
label: BODY

text: persuaded the Examiner erred. We find a preponderance of the evidence
label: H4

text: supports the Examiner’s underlying factual findings and ultimate legal
label: BODY

text: conclusion of obviousness for all contested claims on appeal.

label: BODY

label: BODY
